results.title: Olivia Newton-John, Pop Singer and ‘Grease’ Star, Dies at 73
results.abstract: She amassed No. 1 hits, chart-topping albums and four records that sold more than two million copies each. More than anything else, she was likable, even beloved.

media.caption: Olivia Newton-John starring as Sandy in the 1978 hit movie “Grease.” She was a four-time Grammy winner, beguiling listeners with a high, supple, vibrato-warmed voice.
media.copyright: CBS, via Getty Images

results.adx_keywords: United States Politics and Government;Trump, Donald J;Federal Bureau of Investigation;Justice Department;Palm Beach (Fla)
results.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Ben Protess and Adam Goldman
results.title: The search appears to be focused on materials Trump took from the White House.
results.abstract: The search appeared to be focused on material that the former president had brought to Mar-a-Lago when he left the White House.

media.copyright: Emil Lippe for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Writing and Writers;Books and Literature;Presidents and Presidency (US);Pulitzer Prizes;McCullough, David
results.title: David McCullough, Best-Selling Explorer of America’s Past, Dies at 89
results.abstract: His research — on Adams, Truman and so much more — was deep, his writing was lively, and his narrator’s voice in documentary films was familiar to millions.

media.caption: The author David McCullough in 2001, the year his biography “John Adams” was published. It would go on to win a Pulitzer Prize, his second.
media.copyright: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Books and Literature;United States Politics and Government;Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021);Presidential Election of 2020;Baker, Peter;Glasser, Susan;Trump, Donald J;Milley, Mark A;Meadows, Mark R (1959- );Pompeo, Mike;Joint Chiefs of Staff
results.title: Trump Asked Aide Why His Generals Couldn’t Be Like Hitler’s, Book Says
results.abstract: The former president once asked his chief of staff why his military leadership couldn’t be more like the German generals who had reported to Adolf Hitler, according to an excerpt.

media.caption: Gen. Mark A. Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff under President Donald J. Trump, once drafted a resignation letter accusing the president of embracing the tyranny, dictatorship and extremism that the military had sworn to fight.
media.copyright: Sarahbeth Maney/The New York Times

results.title: Maps in Four States Were Ruled Illegal Gerrymanders. They’re Being Used Anyway.
results.abstract: A Supreme Court shift, frowning on changes close to elections, gives House Republicans a big advantage in November.

media.caption: State Senator Rodger Smitherman compared congressional district maps during a special session on redistricting at the Alabama Statehouse in Montgomery in November 2021.
media.copyright: Mickey Welsh/The Montgomery Advertiser, via Associated Press

results.title: I Didn’t Want It to Be True, but the Medium Really Is the Message
results.abstract: How we look matters as much as what we see.

media.copyright: Photo Illustration by Pelle Cass

results.adx_keywords: Homeless Persons;Frauds and Swindling;D'Amico, Mark;McClure, Kate;Bobbitt, Johnny Jr;GoFundMe;New Jersey
results.title: New Jersey Man Gets 5 Years in Prison in GoFundMe Fraud Case
results.abstract: Prosecutors said Mark D’Amico and his then-girlfriend made up a heartwarming tale of a homeless man to help raise more than $400,000.

media.caption: Johnny Bobbitt Jr., left, Mark D’Amico and Katelyn McClure at a gas station in Philadelphia in 2017. Mr. D’Amico was sentenced on Friday to five years in New Jersey state prison for his role in a fund-raising fraud, officials said.
media.copyright: Elizabeth Robertson/The Philadelphia Inquirer, via Associated Press

results.title: The Problem With Wine Bottles
results.abstract: They may be a perfect container for aging wine, but glass bottles contribute enormously to climate change.

media.caption: Cases of wine ready to be shipped from a warehouse in southern France.
media.copyright: Daniel Cole/Associated Press

results.byline: By Neelam Bohra and Vimal Patel
results.title: Killings of 4 Men in Albuquerque Leave Muslim Community in Fear
results.abstract: As the authorities appeal to the public for help in their investigation, many Muslim residents are experiencing a “managed panic.”

media.caption: A private security guard patrolling the Islamic Center of New Mexico in Albuquerque on Sunday.
media.copyright: Adria Malcolm for The New York Times

results.title: We Went on a Lanternfly-Killing Rampage. They’re Still Here.
results.abstract: The spotted lanternfly, an invasive pest that ecologists have urged the populace to squish on sight, is back, infesting the New York City area.

media.caption: The invasive lanternfly can hurt plants and trees, but not people or animals. Scientists have encouraged people to stomp them on sight.
media.copyright: Dave Sanders for The New York Times

results.title: Two in Arbery Case Sentenced Again to Life in Prison; Third Man Gets 35 Years
results.abstract: The men were convicted of federal hate crimes after state murder convictions in 2021. Their lawyers tried without success to have part of their sentences served in federal prison.

media.caption: Travis McMichael, left, and his father, Gregory McMichael, in the courtroom during the state murder trial in November.
media.copyright: Pool photo by Stephen B. Morton

results.adx_keywords: Swimming Pools;Real Estate and Housing (Residential);United States
results.title: Don’t Call It a Swimming Pool
results.abstract: Plunge pools have become an alternative for homeowners who want a simple, less expensive way to cool off.

media.caption: “We really wanted just a ‘cocktail pool’ that we could dip in, have some drinks, have some friends over. We just didn’t want a big pool,” said homeowner Amy Holland, whose plunge pool (seen here) did not interfere with the lengthy root system of the 100-year-old live oak on the property.
media.copyright: Katherine Squier for The New York Times

results.abstract: The digital media company’s founders, Jim VandeHei, Mike Allen and Roy Schwartz, will continue to run the company.

results.adx_keywords: Presidents and Presidency (US);Law and Legislation;United States Politics and Government;Trump, Donald J;Clinton, Hillary Rodham;Mukasey, Michael B
results.title: If Trump broke a law on the removal of official records, would he be barred from future office?
results.abstract: An obscure criminal law bars the removal of official records, on penalty of disqualification from holding any federal office. But it may not play out that way.

media.caption: Boxes were moved out of the Eisenhower Executive Office building inside the White House complex near the end of President Donald J. Trump’s term.
media.copyright: Gerald Herbert/Associated Press

results.title: What’s in the Climate, Tax and Health Care Package
results.abstract: The bill includes billions in tax credits for the production of renewable energy, drug-pricing reforms and a boost for the I.R.S.

media.caption: A petrochemicals refinery unit in Port Arthur, Texas. Legislation on the verge of Senate passage would be the largest single U.S. investment in fighting climate change.
media.copyright: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times

results.title: After a First Date at Popeyes, Marriage Was on the Menu
results.abstract: Sharhea Wade was ready to forget about Stevenson Boyce, whom she met on Hinge, because he twice canceled their first date. But soon after a third (successful) attempt, she was ready to marry him.

media.copyright: Yuri Vaysgant

results.adx_keywords: Electric and Hybrid Vehicles;Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions;Inflation Reduction Act of 2022;Used Cars;Law and Legislation;Global Warming;Automobiles;Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates);Tesla Motors Inc
results.title: Electric Cars Too Costly for Many, Even With Aid in Climate Bill
results.abstract: Battery-powered vehicles are considered essential to the fight against climate change, but most models are aimed at the affluent.

media.caption: Ford has stopped taking orders for Lightning electric pickups, with a theoretical starting price of about $40,000, because it can’t make them fast enough.
media.copyright: Sylvia Jarrus for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Airlines and Airplanes;Anxiety and Stress;Flight Attendants;Travel and Vacations;Customs, Etiquette and Manners;Content Type: Service
results.title: 20 Years at 30,000 Feet: A Flight Attendant Answers Readers’ Questions
results.abstract: Does the cabin crew ever get scared in the air? Is there a secret flight attendant code? How do I survive a flight with my toddler? An industry insider answers.

media.caption: One of the biggest misconceptions about the job? That it’s glamorous. “One night I can be sitting by the ocean, sipping prosecco with fresh seafood, and the next I can be eating a four-day-old sandwich in my galley.”
media.copyright: Hannah Agosta

results.title: Liz Cheney Is Ready to Lose. But She’s Not Ready to Quit.
results.abstract: The Republican says her crusade to stop Donald J. Trump will continue — even if she loses her primary next week. Restoring a “very sick” G.O.P. will take years, she says, “if it can be healed.”
org_facet: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
